Process.pseudocode: For all of the results returned that represent a named payment amount, set PaymentAmountName to the named amount returned in result. The named amounts are: MinimumDue, RemainingMinimumDue, LastStatementBalance, RemainingLastStatementBalance, CurrentBalance, and RemainingCurrentBalance. For the case where the minimum due, last statement balance, and current balance are all the same and callers just confirm that they want to pay that amount, use last statement balance

Process.pseudocode:
IF Currency Amount exceeds Current Balance
ELIF Currency Amount less is than $1 IF Currency Amount does not match any named balance under $1

Convert Input currency string to dollars and cents and store in CurrencyAmountInDollarsAndCents Convert Input currency string to dollars only (assume cents were omitted) and store result in CurrencyAmountInDollars
IF CurrencyAmountInDollarsAndCents exceeds Current Balance
ELIF CurrencyAmountInDollarsAndCents less is than $1 and currency amount does not match any named balance amount under $1 IF Multiplying by 100 does not exceed CB
ELSE
ELIF CurrencyAmountInDollarsAndCents is less than $10, and the last 2 digits don't match the cents for LSB or CB and multiplying by 100 does not exceed CB

which is the maximum amount you can pay.

Set PaymentAmount based on ttCurrencyString meaning dollars and cents

Process.pseudocode:
IF PostedPendingOrScheduledPaymentsThisCycle is true and PaymentAmount is less than Remaining Minimum Due
ELIF PostedPendingOrScheduledPaymentsThisCycle is false and PaymentAmount is less than Minimum Due

prompt.text: To set up a bank account for payment, we'll need your bank's routing number and your checking account number, both of which can be found at the bottom of one of your checks.

First, look at the bottom of your check and find the two sets of numbers on the line that starts in the lower left hand corner. The first set of nine numbers is your bank's routing number. It will start with 0, 1, 2, or 3.
Now that you have your check, find your bank's routing number, which is the first of the two sets of numbers on the line that starts in the lower left hand corner. It will start with 0, 1, 2, or 3.

If you need time to go find a check, say Hold On or press the pound key. If you have a check, look for the two sets of numbers on the line that starts in the lower left hand corner. The first set of nine numbers is your bank's routing number. It will start with 0, 1, 2, or 3.
